text:
Training has been a really
critical step in helping get

not only the technologists
and our developers,

but our product people
associated with the tech side

and all of the support
groups to kind of get
to a common lexicon.

We partnered with the AWS
Skills Guild Team to build

Be Cloudy, which is on
demand self-paced learning.
We have this baseline on demand structure

that we've augmented with
Game Jams, Game Days, a lot

of different, in real
life hands-on experiences
to really support those learning pathways.
Be Cloudy has 14 very specific pathways

matching different roles
in our technology org.
Now we're partnering to look at

how we can do more
cohort-based learning, so that

we can really build small
teams to support each other.
So, I think the AWS Skills Guild team
has really helped benefit our developers

and our engineers in a
couple different ways.

For a number of people, this
is their first real experience
working in cloud,

and so being able to
do it in a really fun,

supportive environment gives
people confidence to do things
that they maybe wouldn't have done before,
which is, you know, giving teams

and individuals the opportunity
to train at their own pace,

to kind of get to this certain
level of cloud literacy.
Then going in with their teams

to start building actual
production services

and find new ways to solve
business problems through,
you know, cloud native services.
So it's empowering individuals,

but it's also helping get
more workloads into the cloud,
which is awesome.
